subject: Leadership
title: Kant and Duty-Based Ethics
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Kant and Duty-Based Ethics.

hook.text: Some things are just wrong, regardless of the outcome. Kant said morality comes from duty, not from results.

buildup.text: The categorical imperative: act only as you'd want everyone to act. If lying were universal, trust would collapse.

discovery.text: Kant's second rule: never use people merely as means. Employees aren't tools. They have dignity and deserve respect.

twist.text: Rigid duty ethics can paralyze. Is it wrong to lie to protect someone? Kant would say yes. Most leaders disagree.

climax.text: Use Kant as a check: would I be comfortable if this action became universal policy? If not, reconsider.

punchline.text: Rules without exceptions are dangerous. But exceptions without rules are worse.

quiz.question: What is Kant's categorical imperative?
options: Act only as you'd want everyone to act universally
Follow your instincts in every situation
